column4: I am using xbindkeys to rebind my audio play/pause key to send a custom command to a program that doesn't catch it by default. I also want it to do the original command as well, but I don't know how to make it send the "default" command -- does anyone know?
what's the default command?
I don't know. But it play/pauses all normal media players
it's probably just some other daemon catching it
Right! Is there any sort of way to trace down what is catching it?
I don't know of a good way offhand.  But maybe try having your xbindkeys command emit that button press again (I think this will put it in some infinite loop, but hey might as well try)
yeah I suspect that will happen. But maybe if I have it emit that key first! And then do the next command.
I guess the next question is how to trigger a keyboard command via a script
there are a few options.  You can use xmacroplay or xvkbd for example
Right on. Thank you. Seems like there are a ton. I'll try it!
an xvkbd example: /usr/bin/xvkbd -xsendevent -text "\[Control_L]\[Page_Up]    And an xmacroplay example: echo ButtonPress 2 | xmacroplay -d 0 :0.0   (I don't know if either will work for you)

and yeah I'd be surprised if it doesn't start looping.  If it does the only thing I can think of doing is looking at all the running programs you have for your user, guess which one might be handling key presses, and then looking for documentation.  I haven't used unity/gnome in a while though, so I'm not sure.  It may even be cooked into the window manager or something which would make it more of a
Understood. I bet it's cooked into Unity or Compiz.
reading through http://wiki.videolan.org/DBus-spec might give some hints on the dbus front
danke

also, check out the mpris-remote package.  It may not be exactly how the media players are controlled now, but it may let you accomplish the same thing (control a bunch of media players in a uniform way (which is actually the goal of mpris))
I think I may have it!
I will look into that if not

seemingly if I do this command: dbus-send --type=method_call --print-reply --dest=org.mpris.MediaPlayer2.clementine /org/mpris/MediaPlayer2 org.mpris.MediaPlayer2.Player.PlayPause specifically Clementine will play/pause. So I may be able to work with this
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1797848 script for controlling dbus that may give additional hints
ok, I will stop spamming you now :)
.......Well this last script does 100% exactly what I wanted.
I'd still check out mpris-remote though
